coverImage.title: Me fenced in as a little kid
coverImage.alt: Spoiler: I didn't like being fenced in as a kid.

content.value: Hey, my name's Andrew. This is a story about my life—but it's a story about your life, too. Five years ago, I graduated from a liberal arts college with a fancy degree and $50,000 in student loan debt...sound familiar?

If you're like me, you probably landed a full-time job where you could work the "right" hours, earn the "right" amount of money, and gain the "right" experience. Maybe you even made the "right" move by quitting to start your own business.
But after living the "A Life" for years...
Are you as creative as you'd like to be?
Or are you still stuck—like a tiny cog in a huge machine?
You can be more than a cog.

While escaping the 9–5 world can be a great first step toward actual freedom, a lot of freelancers find themselves even more trapped and even less happy than when they were working a corporate gig. How is that possible?
I'll tell you. It's all about the "lines."

Lines are rules. They're the social guard rails, the things you're "supposed" to do—the tracks you're expected to follow because that's "just the way things are." These lines are meant to make us feel safe and normal: if you just keep your head down and work hard enough, everything will be alright.
Studies consistently show that most Americans are living paycheck–to–paycheck: in 2016, nearly half the people surveyed by the Federal Reserve Board said they would have a hard time coming up with

If you and I continue going down the same beaten path, we're going to spend the rest of our lives trading time for money, until we have been ground into the earth by the weight of other people's success—like that guy in the sandwich line wearing a back brace and wrist guard just to make it through the day.
It doesn't matter whether you're a CEO or a sandwich-maker. If you keep following the "lines," if you keep chasing the "A Life," you will always be just
. Because, frankly, the working world is DESIGNED to squeeze every last ounce of energy and productivity out of you—while someone else reaps the profit.
What is F the Lines, really?

Finance buffs will teach you how to make money. Creative experts will help you improve your technical skills. Business gurus will advise you on starting a business. But most of the resources available to you are focused on making you better at FOLLOWING the rules.
Where can you go to learn how to break them? Who can help you combine all that raw experience and knowledge into a kind of life that doesn't exist yet?
I don't have all the answers.
But I created F the Lines to find them.

Over the next four months (April 1st to August 1st), I'm going to be posting weekly articles on creativity, productivity, and happiness—with the end-goal of publishing a simple framework that anyone can use to create a nonconventional business and lifestyle. For anyone tuning in later, that's OK. I'll send you the backlog.

If you want to come along with me, you can subscribe below to get weekly articles with 100% actionable insights and tips. Sound helpful? Keep reading, I'm going to cover the topics I have planned and share a few articles to get you started.

When I said I don't have the answers, I meant it. What I do have is questions. I'm going to explore one of those questions each week and share the results until I accomplish my personal goals: buying and converting a camper van, starting a podcast, and switching to life on the road (more on this in my blueprint article next week). Any topics not yet linked are subject to change.

title.en-US: How to Escape Your 9–5 Job By Saving Time, Money & Energy

summary.en-US: Whether you're trying to start freelancing or level up an existing business, there are three resources you need to make the leap. Here's how to save them.

content.value: to help you figure out who you are and what kind of life/business you need to build if you’re going to be truly free. This week is all about SAVING. Why? Well, let me illustrate by jumping back in time a few years to when I was still slaving away in the corporate world…

I’ve been working as a copywriter at an agency in NJ for more than a year. I hate it; it’s absolutely soul-crushing. The clients are evil and/or boring, the meetings never end, the culture is toxic, and, worst of all, the job is a dead-end with no potential for growth. I need to get out, but I’m expending so much energy just trying to SURVIVE on a day-to-day basis that I have absolutely nothing left in the tank. I’m stuck in a vicious cycle.
I know that all you can think about right now is trying to make a break from the 9–5 world, and I’m here to tell you that it’s definitely
BUT…you won’t get very far if you don’t have enough time, money, and energy to make a solid plan. And, trust me, you’re going to need WAY MORE than you think.
you need? And how can you save it up?

Investors and other business folk like to ask the question: “What’s your number?” In other words, how much money do you need to be happy? You might be thinking…damn, what a shallow way to measure happiness. You’re right.
. But, as you’ll see, the resources we’re talking about in this post are all interconnected.
Time is money, money is energy, and energy is happiness.

number is important. For now, though, I want you to focus on a much smaller number: the minimum amount of money you need to survive the next six months. We’re going to calculate this by doing some good-old-fashioned personal accounting. Bear in mind, the smaller you can make this number, the sooner you’re going to be able to escape.
high overhead = less freedom = slow growth.
Taking stock of your monthly expenses
First, let’s create a spreadsheet to record our findings. You can use
, or any other tool you prefer. Log into your bank account and pull up any transactions from last month. Add all your
Next, zoom out to the last three months. For each
(like gas or groceries), add up what you spent, then divide by three to get the average. Drop these in your table, as well. Do a quick brain scan for anything you might have missed.

You now have a list of everything you spend money on, and it’s time to go hunting. For each item on the list, ask yourself: Can I live without this thing for the next six months while I’m grinding on my new ventures? Create a “Non-Essential” column in your table and check off any expenses you can lose. Here are some prime suspects:
Dining out (I’m looking at you, “business lunch”)
Driving everywhere vs walking or biking

Rent is another common expense, but ditching that usually requires some big decisions. If you think you might be able to live at home, mark any apartment-related expenses as non-essential for now, and we’ll come back to them later in this post.

Now that you have your table categorized by importance, add up all the essential items. Where did you land? Back in 2015, I got my expenses down to around $750/mo, which meant I could quit my job and start freelancing full-time.

In addition to monthly expenses, it’s also important to factor in how much money you’re going to have saved up before you quit. Fortunately, I had about $5,000 in the bank when I finally decided to quit. UN-fortunately, there were were still four months left on my lease, so I was practically broke by the time I moved home.

I don’t regret taking the plunge, but the question of WHEN to quit is going to come down to how risk-averse you are and how badly you want to escape your current situation. Saving up enough money to live on for six months will put you in a better position to start freelancing or create a passive income business — clients and customers can smell desperation like sharks can smell blood in the water.

Because I needed money so badly in the beginning, I took on clients I shouldn’t have…and ended up working for pennies. Of course, this is part of the learning process, but too many failures can leave you in a emotional hole that’s hard to climb out of.
If you struggled just to carve out enough time to write a
last week, then it’s going to be difficult for you to launch a side hustle, let alone scale it into a full-on freedom business that allows you live the kind of life you’re imagining.

The good news is you probably have a lot more time than you think you do. Let’s find out by using the same process we applied to our monthly expenses. Yup, you guessed it: we need to create another table. Here’s my list…

I was occupied for 157 hours out of a potential 168 hours per week, which left me with 11 hours — around 1.5 hours per day. Mind you, those were LOW-QUALITY hours, because I was already mentally exhausted from working at a job I hated all day.
How’s your list looking? Pretty brutal? That’s ok, because we’re about to wave a magic wand and free up the time you need to start working on a better life.

I’m guessing the biggest time block on your list is your full-time job. Along with your expenses and savings, it’s important to factor in how emotionally taxing your current position is (aka “meh” or “I fucking hate this, get me out of here right now”). You should also consider how much potential there is for you to develop relevant skills.

My copywriting job was literally sucking the life out of me. Worse, because the agency was so hierarchical and conservative, I couldn’t learn by trial-and-error. That lack of entrepreneurial freedom slowed my personal development down to a snail’s pace.

If you’re learning a lot at your current job and it isn’t too stressful, then you might want to stay on full-time for a year or two…just don’t get too comfy (unless golden handcuffs turn out to be your thing).

Asking you boss to work from home or scale back to part-time hours can be a good middle ground if you’re not ready to freelance full-time. Ideally, you want to be bringing in $1,000/mo or more before you decide to quit for good.

You know what’s coming in this section. While quitting your job might be a relief, cutting out the fun stuff won’t be so easy. If you’re looking for some motivation and you have ten minutes or so to spare, watch
, where Chris Do (Blind CEO and business coach) helps Sean Campbell (a young gun designer) figure out how to go from a gas station attendant to an in-demand logo expert.

title.en-US: Chris Do and Sean Campbell: how to free up time and energy

content.value: Now that you’re fired up, go through your time table and cross off anything that’s nonessential to your personal growth. If you absolutely cannot give something up (Game of Thrones, etc), turn it into a once-a-week reward for completing key goals. When I moved home in March of 2016, I gave up video games, movies, hanging out with friends, and (of course) my full-time job:

Overall, I managed to free up 90 hours per week — the feeling of being back in control of my life had an unbelievably positive effect on my level of motivation and productivity. Those first few months, I would practically jump out of bed in the morning (like it was Christmas), because I couldn’t wait get to the computer and start designing or writing code.
How much time did you carve back into your life? Tweet it to me

Remember when I told you how starting a freelance career without any money saved can put you in a bad spot? Well, a few months after I quit my job and moved home, my bank account was down under a hundred dollars and it seemed like I wouldn’t even make it through the month.

One of my clients needed to publish an illustrated book for her company, so I jumped at the opportunity. I had almost no experience with illustration or print design, but I thought I could learn on the job. It ended up being way more difficult than I imagined, and the stress, combined with a couple deaths in my family, pitched me over the edge.

Ultimately, I realized that the things I thought were giving me energy (YouTube, browsing design inspiration, arguing on Reddit) were actually sucking me dry. Three years later, I started F the Lines, and one of my first posts was on
. You can read it if you want the whole story, but I’m going to summarize the main points here.
There’s a lot of confusion around what creative block actually is, but I think it’s pretty simple:
Creative block is a shortage of mental energy that results from consistently inputting more than you output.

If you had a rough time trying to decide what to cut out of your life in the “Saving Time” section, then revisit it with this filter in mind. If you’re doing something active (cooking, running, learning new techniques), keep doing it; if you’re passively consuming something, stop — or, at least, turn it into a less frequent reward for completing goals.
We’ve caught a lot of obvious time leeches, already. But some of the worst offenders can be more sneaky. Let’s say you procrastinate doing the dishes. Even though you’re technically not
anything, every time you walk by the dishes, your brain has to think about them and then make a decision to ignore them. Not to quote
If you choose not to decide, you still have made a choice.

That tiny interaction isn’t enough to tax your brain. HOWEVER, multiply that by the number of times you walk through the kitchen (not to mention all the other things you put off), and it becomes clear how much energy you’re wasting. Your brain has a limited budget, and like spending real money, you can be a millionaire and still go broke making tiny purchases all day long.
we spend our time, we can also change what we
about the time we spend. The default for most creative people is to criticize their work: “Nothing I do is good enough.” This
acts as a stop sign — halting progress and inducing creative block.
A more effective strategy is to treat self-criticism as a railroad switch: “I did something creative, and here are two ways I could make it even better.” The idea is to use the “

” rule (a la improvisational comedy) to continually slingshot yourself forward, instead of getting stuck. By lowering the bar for “creative” and “output,” you can bypass the punishing critic and actually end up with a much higher-quality result than you thought was possible.

Whether you decide to quit your job now, go part-time, or stay on for a couple more years, the strategies we talked about today are essential to staying productive and creative. Rather than fluid and infinite, I want you to start thinking of your time, money, and energy as limited resources that you need to protect and spend wisely.
Store the tables you made today somewhere safe, and keep reviewing or adding to them as your priorities change. If you want to take a deeper dive into managing your day-to-day energy, you can read
on how I learned to slay creative block for good.

It took me almost four years to figure out how to funnel my freelance work into a profitable business model. Like a lot of creative “entrepreneurs,” I did things completely backwards — but I want help you grow 10x faster. So, next week we’re going to be talking about how to properly start a business. The first step is defining your target audience. Psyched? Me too.
So look out for that email. The subject line is “Defining your target audience.” If you’re not already subscribed to the
to get weekly updates with 100% actionable advice sent straight to your inbox.
If you’re ready to start making some serious changes and pursue the life you want, let’s connect. You can get weekly advice by subscribing to the Framework Journey series

title.en-US: Finding Your Tribe: How to Define a Killer Target Audience

description.en-US: Photo by Tom Pottiger on Unsplash

summary.en-US: Whether you want to be a musician or design expert you won't get far without an audience. This week, we're learning how to become a leader worth following.

content.value: series, you’ve mapped out a life blueprint and parted the Red Sea of stress that was preventing you from

Whether you decided to go part-time, start a side hustle, or full-out quit, this week is going to be fun. We’re going to start building our freedom business by zeroing in on the types of people we can connect with.

This is often referred to as finding your “audience,” but I like the word “tribe” because it’s more dramatic. After all, we’re not just looking for people to listen to us or buy our stuff. We want to create a community that grows over time — a band of like-minded warriors (lovers, etc) who will rally around a meaningful idea.
So, how do we do that?
It helps to understand that there are two basic types of followers:
For example, a musician has fans who will pay to see a live show (supporting), while a fitness coach has students who will pay for a private session so they can get in shape (becoming).
I bet you’ve taken on these roles at different times in your life. And the easiest way to figure out who
followers might be is to step into the shoes of a younger self — what problems were you dealing with at the time? How did you solve them?

First, in a new page (Google Docs, Notion, your notebook, etc), create a table with four columns: Archetype, Follower, Motivation, Desired State. In column one, copy over your top five archetypes from the

In column two, think about the person you were BEFORE you solved a really frustrating problem related to that archetype. For example: when I feel uncreative, I become a Consumer. I start watching or reading interesting content (Motivation), so I can be inspired, creatively (Desired State).
Go ahead and fill out the rest of your table. You can use mine as a reference.

Done? Nice. Even though you don’t know WHAT kind of business you’re going to create or WHO will be in your tribe, you now have a general sense of WHY someone might follow you. Next, let’s back that up by figuring out how you can help your followers grow.
Part 2: Being a Leader Worth Following

It goes without saying that to be a good leader you need to have some valuable skills or qualities. You also need to decide which ones you can build a tribe around. To do that, let’s create a table with the following columns:

Drop in as many pursuits as you can think of, then (for each) check off Passion, Ability, Experience, and Knowledge if they apply. In the next couple sections, we’re going to use these resources to build a killer niche.
These are a few of mine…
If you want to build a following, you need be unique — you need to carve out a slice of the universe that no one else owns. There are only two ways to do this:
Be the best at something that already exists (almost impossible)
Be really good at something new (difficult, but doable)
is an example of the first strategy. There are thousands of runners who are
as fast as he is, but no matter how close they come, people aren’t going to remember the second-best runner in the world (let alone the third or forth, etc).
Another word for chasing perfection is “
,” which means a line a that continually approaches a curve, but does not meet it at any finite distance. Seth Godin riffs on this in
: “[People who] earn dramatic success always do it in markets where asymptotes don’t exist, or where they can be shattered.”

General topics like “health and fitness” are really hard to break into. There are a million businesses already serving those audiences (and only a tiny fraction are really successful). The way to get around this is by bringing together two or more generic ideas to create something remarkable.
is a YouTuber who makes loop-based songs with goofy voiceovers and interludes.

title.en-US: Marc Rebillet: Sorry to Bother You

content.value: The dude’s hilarious, musically talented, and wildly imaginative, but he isn’t the best in the world at any of those things. However…because he combined them into an entirely new niche, he was able to go from
How did he do it? No clue. But I can make an educated guess:

People who watch Marc’s videos probably want to be entertained, but more than that, they want to be energized, creatively. It’s hard to find content like that on YouTube — most videos are designed to distract you, not motivate you. Marc solved the problem by combining three of his skills (music, comedy, and improvisation) into a killer niche. To summarize…
Go ahead and create 2–3 niche recipes of your own. What’d you come up with? Tweet your best to me

Creative people want the freedom to explore, but their lack of focus traps them in bad situations and prevents them from becoming financially independent. I’m going to solve that problem by teaching business skills to creatives through writing, conversations with unconventional entrepreneurs, and hands-on experience (learning as I go).
Now that we know what our potential tribe members might be feeling and we’ve carved out a unique solution that could be helpful, let’s figure out where we can actually find them.
To do that, we need to get a little more specific on

these people are. Pick your strongest problem/solution scenario and think about what types of people might be struggling with that issue. Jot down any characteristics that come to mind. For example, I wrote:
No-bullshit, tell it like it is

The next question to ask is, “Where do these kinds of people hang out?” You will probably have a lot in common with your future tribe members, so you can also ask, “Where did I spend a lot of time when I was __ years old?” Or “…when I was struggling with X,” etc.

Literally imagine their day from the time they wake up to the time they go to sleep. (We’re going to creep a bit in the name of research.) What podcasts do they listen to? What social media apps are they on? Do they go to meetups? Are they buying tickets to tech conferences? Which hashtags or topics are they following?

For my tribe, Reddit and Twitter come to mind first, because that’s where a lot of freelancers go to complain about #clientsfromhell and get advice, etc. I think Medium probably makes sense, as well, because a lot of people are sharing/searching for stories about personal struggles and what they learned. Design conferences or meetups could be helpful — it’s sometimes easier (and quicker) to just meet in person.

Now, to wrap up, let me say that your goal right now is not to start pitching people on a business that doesn’t even exist. The whole point of this article is to help you start generating some authentic connections, so you can get a clearer understanding of why you should create a tribe in the first place:

What do people really want? Why are they struggling? What specific roadblocks are stopping them? What solutions have already tried, and why didn’t they work? What has worked? All this stuff is pure gold, and you’ll find that most people are more than willing to tell you about their problems.
Next Steps: Creating a Business Plan

Alright, troopers. Good work. We’ve laid the groundwork for a killer target audience, and now it’s time for you to get out there and start connecting. Your assignment for this week is to talk with one person each day. If you can handle more, great, but by next week I want you to have connected with at least seven people. Let’s do this!

Next week, we’re gunna get all businessy by creating a solid plan for our new venture. So look out for that email. The subject line is “FTL / Week 4: Creating a Business Plan.” If you’re not already subscribed to the Framework Journey series, you can
If you’re ready to start making some serious changes and pursue the life you want, let’s connect. You can get weekly advice by
or get in touch with me on Twitter
